title: Cannon and marble - forces on marble

This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

Students launch identical marbles of mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> horizontally from a toy cannon of mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="uppercase M sub C is greater than lowercase m sub lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. The cannon can be adjusted to change the launch speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the marble relative to the ground. Each time a marble is launched, the cannon slides backward before coming to rest. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the cannon and the ground is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu). For each launch, the students vary the launch speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and record the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> the cannon slides backward for each launch speed.

Students launch identical marbles of mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> horizontally from a toy cannon of mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="uppercase M sub C is greater than lowercase m sub lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. The cannon can be adjusted to change the launch speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the marble relative to the ground. Each time a marble is launched, the cannon slides backward before coming to rest. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the cannon and the ground is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu). For each launch, the students vary the launch speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and record the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> the cannon slides backward for each launch speed.

(a) Without manipulating equations, briefly describe what happens to the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the cannon slides backward as students increase the launch speed. Explain your reasoning.

(b) Students find the following equation on the Internet to describe the distance <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the cannon slides backward: <math alttext="x equals, the fraction with numerator lowercase m sub lowercase m, end sub, squared, times v squared, and denominator 2 g times mu, end sub, times uppercase M sub C, end sub, squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>g</mi><mi>μ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Whether or not the equation is correct, is it consistent with your prediction in part (a)? Briefly justify your answer.
(c) Without manipulating or stating equations, briefly describe whether the cannon or the marble has more kinetic energy immediately after the marble leaves the cannon. Justify your answer.

(d) Students correctly derive an equation relating the kinetic energy <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the momentum <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of an object: <math alttext="K equals, the fraction p squared over 2 times lowercase m, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is this equation consistent with your description in part (c)? Justify your answer.

Students then discuss the mechanical energy of the marble after it has been launched by the cannon but before it reaches the ground. Both students agree that air resistance is negligible and make the following claims.
Student 1: There are two external forces exerted on the marble while it is in the air, the gravitational force and the force exerted by the cannon. Therefore, the mechanical energy of the marble changes while it is in the air.
Student 2: The cannon does not exert a force on the marble after the launch. Therefore, the mechanical energy of the marble is constant.
(e) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 1’s statement are correct, if either? If neither phrase is correct, write “none.”
(f) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 1’s statement are incorrect, if either? If neither phrase is incorrect, write “none.”
(g) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 2’s statement are correct, if either? If neither phrase is correct, write “none.”
(h) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 2’s statement are incorrect, if either? If neither phrase is incorrect, write “none.”

The graph above shows the horizontal component of the velocity for the marble (dashed line) and the cannon (solid line) relative to the ground. Before time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the marble-cannon system is at rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the marble begins accelerating within the cannon, and at time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the marble leaves the cannon.

(i) Describe how to find the change in the distance between the center of mass of the cannon and the center of mass of the marble from time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume that before time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the center of mass of the marble is at the same position as the center of mass of the cannon.
